Undergrads Prefer Co-ed School,
Only 27% Favor All-Male College
"If I had my druthers," say
approximately half of the Hopkins students answering the
year's final campus opinion poll,
a`I'd rather go discover the joys
Of a co-ed school."
The poll, directed by Dave
Epstein under the general auspices of the Student Council,
aims to ascertain the students'
personal and psychological values as well as their changing
opinions on campus affairs over
a four year period.
This particular poll, which reCeived an enthusiastic student
response, queried the student
body concerning the general attitude toward a program of coordinated union with local women's
Colleges. Only 27% of the students polled expressed the desire
to continue in an all male
'school, though other opportunities were presented.
Favor Coordination
Seventy-seven per cent of the
Students responding to the poll
favored coordination. Such a coardinated program could conceivably be along the lines of the
program set up between Harvard
ane Radcliffe.
A substantial minority, moreover, of twenty-eight percent felt
that such a program of coordination would tend to improve

NO Beer—
Prospective fans for Saturday's lacrosse game between
Maryland and Hopkins are advised that they will be prevented from entering the
stadium with "containers" in
their possession. "Container"
is roughly defined as including
scotch cooler, bottles, beer
cans, etc.
This warning is the result
of a recent policy change
made by the University of
Maryland. The stricture has
been invoked as the result of
student and non-student misconduct at recent Byrd Stadium athletic events, and a series of complaints by parents,
students, and alumni.

Goucher Feelings
The feelings of the girls at

John Gustaitis, who is charged
with the duty of interpreting the
poll's results for the Bureau of
Campus Opinion, is unwilling, as
yet, to interpret this latest poll,
though more discussion of the
poll will be forthcoming.

In the past Epstein has directed the poll on the Student
Council which revealed how little the students know about their
chief governing body, the poll
concerning the institution of a
reading period before exams, and
the poll concerning student interest in a big spring week-end
which resulted in the first big
week-end in Hopkins' history.

Weekend Hits Mark,
Money Breaks Even
"The Weekend cost us about
$12,500 and I'd say we took in
about $12,500," was ex-president
Joe Perotto's estimate of the
financial strength of the first
"Big Weekend."
The former Student Council
head stated that attendance at
the Saturday dance had been
"less than usual" due to the
fact that the dance had coincided
with the Notre Dame senior prom
and several other affairs.
Reporting on the concert Dr.
Wickwire estimated that the
YMCA had grossed about $6400.
from ticket sales. Although figures for expenses were not available, Wickwire was fairly certain
that the "Y" had made money
on the affair. Dr. Wickwire commented,"On the whole the thing
came out well considering the
size of the operation."
Theft
A sadder not to the week-end
was the theft of $805 worth of
decorations at the Saturday
night dance. Cotillion Board
chairman Lanny Berman remarked that unless the decorations are recovered the board
will have to pay for the decorations, thus taking away money
from next year's social activities.
Berman asks that anyone
knowing the whereabouts of the
decorations either contact him
directly (Box 450, telephone
number: 243-7937) or slip a note
In his mailbox giving the location

of the stolen items. Berman
stressed that no punishment of
any kind will be exacted. The
Board merely wants the return
of the merchandise.

Honorary Fraternity ODK Adds
13 Members During Half-Time
The Omicron Delta Kappa
honorary service fraternity
tapped thirteen new members
during half-time of the NavyHopkins lacrosse game last Saturday. Included were eleven students and two honorary members.
Dr. Hugh Dryden, deputy administrator of the National
Aeronautics and Space Administration and Rignal Baldwin,
president of the Alumni Association, were named honorary members.
Students tapped were Al Higley, President of June, 1964; Denniss Donnelly, President of the
BIA; Steve Gitomer, President of
Tau Beta Pi; Joe Gotwals, captain of the baseball team; Dick
Kessler, Editor of the Calendar;
Jim McClaine, Chairman of the
SAC; Irvin Nathan, Co-Editorin-Chief of the News-Letter;

Mike Ratner, captain of the soccer team; John Redfern, President of the YMCA Cabinet;
Homer Schwartz, President of
the "H" Club, and Charles Twyman, treasurer of June, 1963.
Two freshmen were also hon-

ored by the fraternity. Steve
"Lucky" Mallonnee, a midfielder
on the frosh lacrosse team, was
named the outstanding athlete
of the freshman class. Shelley
Earp was honored for his nor..
athletic extra-curricular service.

On Commencement Speakers
The announcement that Dr. Otto F. Kraushaar,
President of Goucher College, will be the principal
speaker at this year's commencement exercises elicits
mixed reactions.
On the one hand, it seems a long overdue gesture
to honor the distinguished philosopher and administrator whose fine work both at Goucher and in the
Greater Baltimore area extends back to 1948. The invitation also seems praiseworthy if by any stretch of the
imagination it may be construed as a portent of things
to come towards increased cooperation with the Towson
school.
On the other hand, one hopes that Hopkins is not
falling into the unfortunate rut of inviting only college
presidents to address the graduates on their last day
at the school. Dr. Kraushaar will be the third university
president to speak here at commencement in the last
four years.
Not every graduation address can be as memorable
as the one at Harvard in 1947 when Secretary of State
Marshall announced what came to be known as the
"Marshall Plan." Yet it is hoped that the speech on
which a student bows out as an undergraduate would
be meaningful and significant to him.
In the event that a "big name" such as Edward R.
Murrow, President Dwight Eisenhower, or Prime Minister Harold MacMillan can not be secured, it might
be far more profitable to invite a prominent member of
the Hopkins faculty to speak. His close observation of
the personality and temperament of the Hopkins undergraduate would render his departing words more useful.
We feel that on the whole the choice of Dr. Kraushaar is a good one and his speech will be worth attending. In the future, however, we recommend that the
commencement speaker be chosen from among our renowned faculty, except in very rare cases.

Orientation
Over the years, each succeeding orientation committee seems bent upon reaching new heights of efficiency and streamlining epitomized by organization
man, Jim McClaine. The philosophy in the past, if any
existed, seems to have been that through a complicated
system of logistical manuevers, the freshmen emerge
after one week with practical details handled and some
spirit of the Hop.
The Administration is fond of the notion that if the
freshmen could be wielded into some kind of cohesive
unit before upper class apathy trickles down,the texture
of the undergraduate body would eventually change.
Logical as it may sound, freshmen dormitories, which
were partially motivated by this thought, have had the
opposite effect with a ten percent increase in fraternity
pladging.
It seems to us that orientation should not convince,
convert, wield, or wangle but convey. Hopkins' great
measure of freedom and challenging academic environment presents great problems for incoming freshmen.
Lack of restriction and necessary self-discipline are
more difficult to handle at first but are great assets
which Hopkins offers. When someone leaves Homewood
after four years, he knows how to fend for himself.
Orientation should try its level best to tell the
freshman exactly what Hopkins is and what he should
expect. He should be told that his dormitory social program is largely artificial and contrived and that a better
social life can be had off-campus. He should be told that
we are not a rah-rah campus, don't go in for athletics
in a real big way, and have no equivalent to Princeton
riots. And finally, he should be told that a fine education
and pleasant four years can be found here but not in
the ghoul booths.

Dear Sir:
"Exit the honeys in lieu of
being convinced."
This sentence appeared in an
article entitled "The Sad Cafe."
It follows a statement to the
effect that "we of the Hop do
not feel superior."

The dorm students, for the
second week in a row, flowed
out of the Residences and raised
a riot scene. Under the influence
of the approaching Navy game,
their original purpose was to
cheer the Jays; in the milieu,
however, the good intentions of
the movement became lost in
another barrage of "delicate
phrases and water balloons."
The stirred students would not
be confined to the quad. Toward
the old dorms and into the street
they moved, leaving the Colonel
and the Doctor behind. The Hopkins students stood on the
Charles Street sidewalk and the
policemen with their dogs faced
them on the opposite side. Midst
the stalemate, both forces departed, neither the worse for
wear.
Other than the dampening of
a few officers with water balloons, little other physical action
occurred. And such has been the
plight of the domestic, virgin,
Homewood scene this spring.

thought of as "art," but rather
it is "the leap of the imagination by which Picasso recognized
a bull's head in these unlikely
objects that, we feel, only he
could have done." The tension in
the "making" of art, says Janson, is different from the ordiA
nary making, because the artist
never quite knows what he is
making until it is satisfactory
enough for him to display it to
some audience. He never knowi;
how it will be received.
Throughout the survey of art
in the Ancient World, Middle
Ages, Rennaissance, and the
Modern World from "Magic and
Ritual—The Art of Prehistoric
Man" to "Twentieth Century
Architecture" Janson conveys the
spirit of the artist groping to
overcome the resistance of the
"audience," experimenting with
new color techniques as Giotto or
with collages as Braque, to
achieve certainty that what he
has "made is a genuine creation,
a work of art in fact as well as
in intention."
Professor Janson's History of
Art is the most brilliant survey
of its kind on the market. Its
layout, magnificent photographic
illustrations, clear description
and
enlightened
speculation,
combined with a carefully unified
point of view present a massive
and at the same time digestable
introduction into the question,
"what is art?"
"The Early Renaissance,
Italy" seemed to me Janion's
masterpiece, however, his treatment of Roman Art and "Postscript—The Meeting of East and
West" were also extremely interesting (as is the whole volume).
At $9.50 the book is a bargain
to all would-be partisans of art
and deserves to be read and
studied by.all students interested
or engaged in an introductory
course in Art.

The first four finishers in the
Kentucky Derby will be there,
Dr. Hammond told us. Chateuquay, who won the Derby, and
Candy Spots, whom everyone
thought would win, will probably
he the favorites. However, Dr.
Hammond feels that the shorter
track could boost the chances of
the second place finisher, Never
Bend.
Profitless Better
When asked about betting, Dr.
Hammond replied that even he,
and he considers himself better
than the average, could not make
a profit on horseracing today.
The take of the track and the
state combined amounts to about
15% today as compared to about
5% in former, more profitable
days.
However, for the stout-hearted
he had a few suggestions. First
of all, if you know anything
about the horses running, bet to
win. On the other hand, one
often profitable scheme for novices is to take the track selection
in the program and bet him second.
Losers Easy To Pick
It is often easier to pick a
loser than a winner, according
to our professor of philosophy.
One gimmick that sometimes
works is to exclude one, two, or
three horses and bet the others
to win. However, the eminent
doctor still recalls that day down
In Bowie when he covered eight
of nine horses and even that was
not enough.

belief that some day they will pay me for these last nine years.
But working for the makers of Marlboro has not been the
greatest of my pleasures over the last nine years. The chief
satisfaction has been writing for you—the college population
of America. It is a rare and lucky columnist who can find an
audience so full of intelligence and verve. I would like very
much to show my appreciation by asking you all over to my
house for tea and oatmeal cookies, but there is no telling how
many of you my wife would bite.
For many of you this is the last year of college. This is especially true for seniors. To those I extend my heartfelt wishes
that you will find the world outside a happy valley. To juniors
I extend my heartfelt wishes that you will become seniors. To
sophomores I extend my heartfelt wishes that you will become
Juniors. To freshmen I extend my heartfelt wishes that you will
become sophomores. To those of you going on into graduate
school I extend my heartfelt wishes that you will marry money.
To all of you let me say one thing: during the year I have.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MAY 17, 1963

Sluggers Drop Two, End Season
The Varsity baseball squad
completed their season last
Wednesday against Dickinson at
Homewood Field after a wild
week of baseball which saw them
defeated by Loyola 11-8 and
Western Maryland 7-1.
The Loyola game was a wild
contest which saw the Blue Jay

nine behind at one point by ten
runs, 11-1, and come surging
back in the last two innings to
score seven runs and narrowly
miss winning the game.
Western Maryland's fine pitcher, Lance Kline, limited Hopkins
to five hits and did not walk a
man in Western Maryland's 7-1
victory over the Jays on Saturday. The Hopkins outfield col-

lected all five hits, with Joe Gotwals getting two, Charlie Mac-.
Intyre two, and Skip Leiblein one.
Frank Soriano started and did
well for four innings before being
replaced by Ron Kochis. Western
Maryland collected only six hits,
but two doubles and a triple with
men on meant defeat for the
Sachs' nine.

Thinclads Edge W. C.
Tomorrow the Blue Jay cindermen travel to Mount Saint
Mary's for the Mason-Dixon
championships. Coach Mickey
Cochrane feels that Gerry Miller,
John Morgan, and John Cox
could take first places in the 880
yard run, the discus, and the
high hurdles, respectively.
The thin-clads ended their regular season with a 69-62 win over
Washington College.
Conrad Wins
Conrad Gebelein, Phil Berger,
and Gerry Miller placed first,
second, and third in both the
mile and two mile runs. Miller
also won the half-mile run, and
Van Clark placed second in that
event. John Cox took first in the
high hurdles, tying the school
record of 15.1 seconds, and
placed second in the intermediate hurdles. Andy Woodson took

third in the intermediates and
second in the 440 yard dash.
In the sprints, Randy Cockey
took second in the 100 yard dash
and Jeff Kominers took third
in the 220 yard dash.
Cockey Jumps
Cockey won the broad jump
with 20 feet 2% inches, one-half
an inch ahead of the secondplace Washington College competitor. Cockey also took place
in the shot put, won by John
Morgan with a toss of 42 feet
1 inch. Bob Prim took third place
in the javelin by a few inches
with his best effort of the year,
13 feet 8 inches. John Morgan
won the discus for Hopkins with
138 feet 1 inch. Ruben Aaronson
and John Cox took first and second places in the pole vault when
no Washington College vaulter
could clear ten feet.

"The Weekend cost us about

Joe Perotto's estimate of the
financial strength of the first
"Big Weekend."
The former Student Council
head stated that attendance at

fact that the dance had coincided

Wickwire estimated that the
YMCA had grossed about $6400.
from ticket sales. Although figures for expenses were not available, Wickwire was fairly certain

Theft
A sadder not to the week-end
was the theft of $805 worth of
decorations at the Saturday
night dance. Cotillion Board
chairman Lanny Berman remarked that unless the decorations are recovered the board
will have to pay for the decorations, thus taking away money
from next year's social activities.
Berman asks that anyone
knowing the whereabouts of the
decorations either contact him

In his mailbox giving the location

stressed that no punishment of

of the merchandise.

On Commencement Speakers
The announcement that Dr. Otto F. Kraushaar,
President of Goucher College, will be the principal
speaker at this year's commencement exercises elicits
mixed reactions.
On the one hand, it seems a long overdue gesture
to honor the distinguished philosopher and administrator whose fine work both at Goucher and in the
Greater Baltimore area extends back to 1948. The invitation also seems praiseworthy if by any stretch of the
imagination it may be construed as a portent of things
to come towards increased cooperation with the Towson
school.
On the other hand, one hopes that Hopkins is not
falling into the unfortunate rut of inviting only college
presidents to address the graduates on their last day
at the school. Dr. Kraushaar will be the third university
president to speak here at commencement in the last
four years.
Not every graduation address can be as memorable
as the one at Harvard in 1947 when Secretary of State
Marshall announced what came to be known as the
"Marshall Plan." Yet it is hoped that the speech on
which a student bows out as an undergraduate would
be meaningful and significant to him.
In the event that a "big name" such as Edward R.
Murrow, President Dwight Eisenhower, or Prime Minister Harold MacMillan can not be secured, it might
be far more profitable to invite a prominent member of
the Hopkins faculty to speak. His close observation of
the personality and temperament of the Hopkins undergraduate would render his departing words more useful.
We feel that on the whole the choice of Dr. Kraushaar is a good one and his speech will be worth attending. In the future, however, we recommend that the
commencement speaker be chosen from among our renowned faculty, except in very rare cases.

Orientation
Over the years, each succeeding orientation committee seems bent upon reaching new heights of efficiency and streamlining epitomized by organization
man, Jim McClaine. The philosophy in the past, if any
existed, seems to have been that through a complicated
system of logistical manuevers, the freshmen emerge
after one week with practical details handled and some
spirit of the Hop.
The Administration is fond of the notion that if the
freshmen could be wielded into some kind of cohesive
unit before upper class apathy trickles down,the texture
of the undergraduate body would eventually change.
Logical as it may sound, freshmen dormitories, which
were partially motivated by this thought, have had the
opposite effect with a ten percent increase in fraternity
pladging.
It seems to us that orientation should not convince,
convert, wield, or wangle but convey. Hopkins' great
measure of freedom and challenging academic environment presents great problems for incoming freshmen.
Lack of restriction and necessary self-discipline are
more difficult to handle at first but are great assets
which Hopkins offers. When someone leaves Homewood
after four years, he knows how to fend for himself.
Orientation should try its level best to tell the
freshman exactly what Hopkins is and what he should
expect. He should be told that his dormitory social program is largely artificial and contrived and that a better
social life can be had off-campus. He should be told that
we are not a rah-rah campus, don't go in for athletics
in a real big way, and have no equivalent to Princeton
riots. And finally, he should be told that a fine education
and pleasant four years can be found here but not in
the ghoul booths.

The dorm students, for the
second week in a row, flowed
out of the Residences and raised
a riot scene. Under the influence
of the approaching Navy game,
their original purpose was to
cheer the Jays; in the milieu,
however, the good intentions of
the movement became lost in
another barrage of "delicate
phrases and water balloons."
The stirred students would not
be confined to the quad. Toward
the old dorms and into the street
they moved, leaving the Colonel
and the Doctor behind. The Hopkins students stood on the
Charles Street sidewalk and the
policemen with their dogs faced
them on the opposite side. Midst
the stalemate, both forces departed, neither the worse for
wear.
Other than the dampening of
a few officers with water balloons, little other physical action
occurred. And such has been the
plight of the domestic, virgin,
Homewood scene this spring.

never quite knows what he is
making until it is satisfactory
enough for him to display it to
some audience. He never knowi;
how it will be received.
Throughout the survey of art
in the Ancient World, Middle
Ages, Rennaissance, and the
Modern World from "Magic and
Ritual—The Art of Prehistoric
Man" to "Twentieth Century
Architecture" Janson conveys the
spirit of the artist groping to
overcome the resistance of the
"audience," experimenting with
new color techniques as Giotto or
with collages as Braque, to
achieve certainty that what he
has "made is a genuine creation,
a work of art in fact as well as
in intention."
Professor Janson's History of
Art is the most brilliant survey
of its kind on the market. Its
layout, magnificent photographic
illustrations, clear description
and
enlightened
speculation,
combined with a carefully unified
point of view present a massive
and at the same time digestable
introduction into the question,
"what is art?"
"The Early Renaissance,
Italy" seemed to me Janion's
masterpiece, however, his treatment of Roman Art and "Postscript—The Meeting of East and
West" were also extremely interesting (as is the whole volume).
At $9.50 the book is a bargain
to all would-be partisans of art
and deserves to be read and
studied by.all students interested
or engaged in an introductory
course in Art.

The first four finishers in the
Kentucky Derby will be there,
Dr. Hammond told us. Chateuquay, who won the Derby, and
Candy Spots, whom everyone
thought would win, will probably
he the favorites. However, Dr.
Hammond feels that the shorter
track could boost the chances of
the second place finisher, Never
Bend.
Profitless Better
When asked about betting, Dr.
Hammond replied that even he,
and he considers himself better
than the average, could not make
a profit on horseracing today.
The take of the track and the
state combined amounts to about
15% today as compared to about
5% in former, more profitable
days.
However, for the stout-hearted
he had a few suggestions. First
of all, if you know anything
about the horses running, bet to
win. On the other hand, one
often profitable scheme for novices is to take the track selection
in the program and bet him second.
Losers Easy To Pick
It is often easier to pick a
loser than a winner, according
to our professor of philosophy.
One gimmick that sometimes
works is to exclude one, two, or
three horses and bet the others
to win. However, the eminent
doctor still recalls that day down
In Bowie when he covered eight
of nine horses and even that was
not enough.

newspaper—even throughout the prolonged newspaper strike

Marlboro Cigarettes—a fine group of men, as anyone who has
sampled their wares would suspect. They are as mellow as the
aged tobaccos they blend. They are as pure as the white cellulose
filter they have devised. They are loyal, true, companionable,
and constant, and I have never for an instant wavered in my
belief that some day they will pay me for these last nine years.
But working for the makers of Marlboro has not been the
greatest of my pleasures over the last nine years. The chief
satisfaction has been writing for you—the college population
of America. It is a rare and lucky columnist who can find an
audience so full of intelligence and verve. I would like very
much to show my appreciation by asking you all over to my
house for tea and oatmeal cookies, but there is no telling how
many of you my wife would bite.
For many of you this is the last year of college. This is especially true for seniors. To those I extend my heartfelt wishes
that you will find the world outside a happy valley. To juniors
I extend my heartfelt wishes that you will become seniors. To
sophomores I extend my heartfelt wishes that you will become
Juniors. To freshmen I extend my heartfelt wishes that you will
become sophomores. To those of you going on into graduate
school I extend my heartfelt wishes that you will marry money.
To all of you let me say one thing: during the year I have.
been frivolous and funny during the past year—possibly less •
often than I have imagined—but the time has now come for

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MAY 17, 1963

Sluggers Drop Two, End Season
The Varsity baseball squad
completed their season last
Wednesday against Dickinson at
Homewood Field after a wild
week of baseball which saw them
defeated by Loyola 11-8 and
Western Maryland 7-1.
The Loyola game was a wild
contest which saw the Blue Jay

nine behind at one point by ten
runs, 11-1, and come surging
back in the last two innings to
score seven runs and narrowly
miss winning the game.
Western Maryland's fine pitcher, Lance Kline, limited Hopkins
to five hits and did not walk a
man in Western Maryland's 7-1
victory over the Jays on Saturday. The Hopkins outfield col-

lected all five hits, with Joe Gotwals getting two, Charlie Mac-.
Intyre two, and Skip Leiblein one.
Frank Soriano started and did
well for four innings before being
replaced by Ron Kochis. Western
Maryland collected only six hits,
but two doubles and a triple with
men on meant defeat for the
Sachs' nine.

Thinclads Edge W. C.
Tomorrow the Blue Jay cindermen travel to Mount Saint
Mary's for the Mason-Dixon
championships. Coach Mickey
Cochrane feels that Gerry Miller,
John Morgan, and John Cox
could take first places in the 880
yard run, the discus, and the
high hurdles, respectively.
The thin-clads ended their regular season with a 69-62 win over
Washington College.
Conrad Wins
Conrad Gebelein, Phil Berger,
and Gerry Miller placed first,
second, and third in both the
mile and two mile runs. Miller
also won the half-mile run, and
Van Clark placed second in that
event. John Cox took first in the
high hurdles, tying the school
record of 15.1 seconds, and
placed second in the intermediate hurdles. Andy Woodson took

third in the intermediates and
second in the 440 yard dash.
In the sprints, Randy Cockey
took second in the 100 yard dash
and Jeff Kominers took third
in the 220 yard dash.
Cockey Jumps
Cockey won the broad jump
with 20 feet 2% inches, one-half
an inch ahead of the secondplace Washington College competitor. Cockey also took place
in the shot put, won by John
Morgan with a toss of 42 feet
1 inch. Bob Prim took third place
in the javelin by a few inches
with his best effort of the year,
13 feet 8 inches. John Morgan
won the discus for Hopkins with
138 feet 1 inch. Ruben Aaronson
and John Cox took first and second places in the pole vault when
no Washington College vaulter
could clear ten feet.
